Graphical abstract High-entropy-alloys nanoparticles have been applied in catalysis recently. The advances of noble-metal-based high-entropy-alloys nanoparticles towards electrocatalysis are reviewed in detail from the viewpoint of structure–property relationship. Since the two seminal papers were published independently in 2004, high-entropy-alloys (HEAs) have been applied to structural and functional materials due to the enhanced mechanical properties, thermal stability, and electrical conductivity. In recent years, HEA nanoparticles (HEA-NPs) were paid much attention to in the field of catalysis for the promoted catalytic activity. Furthermore, the various ratios among the metal components and tunable bulk and surface structures enable HEAs have big room to enhance the catalytic performance. Especially, noble-metal-based HEAs displayed significantly improved performance in electrocatalysis, where the ‘core effects’ were employed to explain the superior catalytic activity. However, it is insufficient to understand the essential mechanism or further guide the design of electrocatalysts. Structure–property relationship should be disclosed for the catalysis on HEA-NPs to accelerate the process of seeking high effective and efficient electrocatalysts. Therefore, we summarized the recent advances of noble-metal-based HEA-NPs applied to electrocatalysis, such as hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, methanol oxidation reaction, ethanol oxidation reaction, formic acid oxidation reaction, hydrogen oxidation reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction and nitrogen reduction reaction. For each electrocatalytic reaction, the reaction mechanism and catalyst structure were presented, and then the structure–property relationship was elaborated. The review begins with the development, concept, four ‘core effect’ and synthesis methods of HEAs. Next, the electrocatalytic reactions on noble-metal-based HEA-NPs are summarized and discussed independently. Lastly, the main views and difficulties pertaining to structure–property relationship for HEAs are discussed. Keywords Noble-metal-based High-entropy-alloy Nanoparticles ‘Core effects’ Structure–property relationship Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Alloy materials were made and used in the ancient age, which played an extremely important role in the progress of human civilization [1]. Conventionally, one primary metal was selected as major part and alloyed with other elements with a low concentration to obtain particular physical properties [2–7]. In 2004, two pioneering studies were reported, which educed high-entropy concept from crystalline multi-component alloy [8,9]. Specifically, FeCrMnNiCo alloy was developed with high configuration entropy via homogeneously mixing five principal elements in equal atomic ratio [8]. Subsequently, the multi-principal element alloys with disordered solid solution structure were named as high-entropy-alloys (HEAs) [9]. Different from traditional alloys, HEAs are able to surmount the huge immiscible gap between different elements, forming a stable single-phase solid solution structure instead of phase-separated materials or intermetallic compounds [10]. Since HEAs were reported, numerous innovative high-entropy materials (HEMs) including high-entropy metallic glasses (HEMGs) [11–13], high-entropy oxides (HEOs) [14], and high-entropy van der Waals materials [15] have been synthesized, possessing excellent thermodynamic stability, unique ductility, superior corrosion resistance and outstanding fracture resistance [16–18]. Recently, HEAs have attracted tremendous interests in sustainable energy storage and conversion. 1.1 Definition and property of HEAs Since entropy is a thermodynamic state function, the change, Δ S , depends on the difference between the initial and final states instead of the path [1]. According to Boltzmann hypothesis, the configuration entropy ( Δ S m i x ) during the formation of the alloy system can be given as: (1) Δ S m i x = - k B l n ω = - R ∑ i = 1 n c i l n c i , where k B is Boltzmann’s constant, ω is the probability of a given system state, R is the molar gas constant and c i is the molar fraction of component i, and n is the number of types of elements [19,20]. Eq. (1) can be simplified as Δ S m i x = R l n n when multi-component alloys are mixed in equal atomic ratio. Therefore, Δ S m i x of the ternary, quaternary, quinary, senary, and novenary alloy systems with equal atomic ratios can be deduced as 1.10R, 1.39R, 1.61R, 1.79R and 2.20R, respectively. Obviously, Δ S m i x of the alloy system increases with the number of elements as shown in Fig. 1 (a). Taking the novenary alloy system as an example, it shows a colossal Δ S m i x of 2.20R, nearly 2 times higher than that of ternary alloy, indicating that alloy systems with more constituent elements are likely to obtain stronger entropy driving force [21]. (2) Δ G mix = Δ H mix - T Δ S mix , where Δ G mix is mixed Gibbs free energy, and Δ H mix is mixed configuration enthalpy. According to the conclusion above, if Δ S mix of an alloy system is large enough, thermodynamic contribution of the mixed configuration entropy ( Δ S mix ) in Eq. (2) to Gibbs free energy is adequate to compensate for the enthalpy of formation ( Δ H mix ), and random alloy is favorably maintained rather than intermetallic compounds because of the negative Δ G mix . Hence, in terms of the early definition of HEA by Yeh et al., alloys composed of five or more elements with compositions between 5% and 35% are considered as HEAs [9]. In particular, single-phase multi-principal element alloy belongs HEAs [22]. However, CrCoNi and PtPdRhRu alloys reported in recent years still presented a single-phase solid solution structure although the number of constituent elements was less than five [23,24]. To define HEAs, the alloys with Δ S m i x ≥ 1.5R or the quaternary alloys with Δ S m i x ≥ 1.36R were considered as HEAs based on the definition of high entropy [2,10,21,25]. The definitions above towards HEAs encompass a wide scope of alloys even if there are still some controversies. In brief, alloys containing at least 5 elements with high concentration (based on composition) and Δ S m i x ≥ 1.5R (based on entropy) can be identified as HEAs. Single-phase solid solution HEAs are able to form various crystal structures, such as face-centered cubic (fcc), body-centered cubic (bcc) [26,27], hexagonal close-packed (hcp) [28] and orthorhombic (orth) [29] crystal structures. Four ‘core effects’ of HEAs were proposed for catalysis (Fig. 1b): (1) high-entropy effect in thermodynamics; (2) sluggish diffusion effect in kinetics; (3) lattice distortion effect in structure; (4) cocktail effect in properties. High entropy effect is the main concept, which is basically employed to explain the single-phase alloy system with multiple principal elements. According to the classical Gibbs phase rule, the number of phases in a given alloy system at constant pressure is defined as follow: (3) P = n + 1 - F , where P is the number of phases formed in equilibrium, n is the number of constituent elements, and F is the degree of freedom for an alloy system. For example, a quinary alloy system theoretically presents six equilibrium phases at a given pressure. However, the quinary alloy system can form a stable single solid solution phase, much smaller than the phase number calculated by the Gibbs phase rule (Eq. (3)). An alloy system with large Δ S m i x at a sufficiently high temperature is more likely to overcome the effect of Δ H mix and form a homogeneously mixed single-phase solid solution structure according to Eq. (2). In other words, high mixing entropy is capable to increase the solubility limit of each element in alloy system, thereby promoting further dissolution of the element-rich phase, and finally forming a stable single phase. Consequently, high-entropy effect explains why the number of phases formed in HEA system is much smaller than that calculated by the simplified theoretical prediction. Sluggish diffusion effect is closely associated with the lattice distortion in alloys. Severe lattice distortion increases the energy barrier for atoms to be activated and migrated, thereby greatly reducing the diffusion rate of atoms in an alloy system. Monte-Carlo molecular dynamics simulation was applied to compare the self-diffusion coefficients of Ru in quinary HEAs and binary RuNi alloys (Fig. 2 a) [30]. The results showed that the self-diffusion coefficients of Ru in the binary alloy exhibited an expressive two orders of magnitude higher than that in the quinary HEAs, suggesting that the stability of quinary HEAs was significantly improved by the lattice distortion. More importantly, even though the quinary HEAs were annealed at high temperatures and tested for ammonia decomposition under harsh conditions, the particle size remained uniform without phase separation. Lattice distortion effect is caused by atoms occupy deviation affected by the other atoms with different particle sizes. For a pristine metal, the crystal surface is flat because of the regular arrangement of the atoms with the identical atomic radii in the crystal lattice. On the contrary, the random arrangement of atoms with distinct radii makes the HEA crystal plane uneven. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was applied to quantitatively analyze HEA formation by adding principal elements from a pure element to seven elements (Fig. 2b) [31]. The results showed that the XRD peak intensities significantly dropped with the increase of the number of principal elements, suggesting that the addition of multi-principal elements with different atomic sizes induced lattice distortion. The lattice distortion effect greatly not only improves the hardness of HEAs, but also dramatically changes the chemical properties [32,33]. Cocktail effect refers to the unexpected synergies resulting from mixing multiple components of various properties which enhance the performance [10]. Many results have proved that the performance of HEAs is not a simple addition of the properties of each element, but it is unpredictable [34]. Initially, the cocktail effect explained the special physical properties of superelastic alloys [35]. The synergistic mechanism of multi-component mixing in HEAs was also employed to explain the unique catalytic performance [36]. 1.2 Overview of the application of HEAs in electrocatalysis Generating electricity by clean energy sources such as wind, water and sun light is not only a promising way to reduce the consumption of fossil fuels, but also sustainable. Electricity, however, needs to be stored and delivered to balance supply and demand. Utilizing electric energy to convert H2O, CO2, N2 into chemicals with high energy density has been paid much attention to [37]. Moreover, electrochemical approaches exhibit higher selectivity and conversion rate compared with conventional thermal chemical processes. However, most electrocatalysts suffered short-term stability in structure and high over-potential for electrochemical conversions [38,39]. Therefore, designing highly efficient materials for electrochemical conversion is extremely important. In recent years, HEAs as a new type of catalyst for electrocatalytic reactions have been received much attention. Carbothermal shock method [40] and fast-moving bed pyrolysis method [41] were developed, but they suffered from a high temperature and low productivity. Solvothermal method [24] and one-pot polyol method [42] were low-temperature methods compared with the methods mentioned above. In addition, diverse innovative synthetic routes were developed in the past few years [43–46], including dealloying [47], sputtering deposition [48], ultrasonic-assisted wet chemical method [49], and nanodroplet-mediated electrodeposition [13]. Overall, the predominant challenge of synthesizing HEA-NPs is co-reduction of all metal precursors. Mono-component materials including noble metals (Pt, Pd, Ir, Os, Ru, Rh, Au, and Ag) [50–59] and 3d transition metals (Cu, Fe, Ni, etc.) [60–62], bi-component and tri-component alloys were widely applied and investigated before HEAs were applied to catalysis. To date, some review articles have been published to summarize the current status of the synthesis of HEMs and their applications [1,10,33,34,63–72]. It is known that noble metals and their alloys are the most widely used materials for electrocatalysis. Therefore, noble-metal-based HEAs will be especially important and predominant in the future. As shown in Fig. 3 , noble-metal-based HEA-NPs for electrocatalytic applications are blossoming recently. However, a detailed discussion on the structural roles of noble-metal-based HEA-NPs in the electrocatalytic performance is still lacking. In this review, the electrocatalytic applications of noble-metal-based HEA catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), methanol oxidation reaction (MOR), ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR), formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR), hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR), and N2 reduction reaction (N2RR) are introduced, and then the corresponding structure–property relationships are summarized. Finally, we propose the main views and difficulties of HEAs related to structure–property relationship, and the catalytic applications of other novel HEMs are also prospected. HEA-NPs with multiple composition and modulation capability result in various electronic and geometric structures on the particle surface, thus providing a nearly continuously changed adsorption energy for reactants and key intermediates to drive optimally catalytic reactions [73]. However, the study of the promotion of HEAs is still at the preliminary stage due to the complicated nature of the multicomponent HEAs and their interactions. Currently, four ‘core effects’ have been extensively applied to explain the superior performance of HEA-NPs. High-entropy effect and sluggish diffusion effect confine HEA-NPs in a single-phase, leading to the distinct thermodynamic and kinetic stability. Lattice distortion effect is capable to optimize the electronic structure around surface active sites, and cocktail effect explains the synergistic effect of multi-components [10,19,33,34]. Although ‘core effects’ generally illustrate the high catalytic activity and stability of HEA-NPs from the perspective of structure–property relationships in most cases, it has been questioned. For example, the quantum size effect inevitably occurs if the alloy particle is at nanoscale size, and the rapid transformation process may ‘passivate’ the sluggish diffusion effect [74]. In addition, severe lattice distortion of multi-component alloys may even directly lead to intermetallic compounds, which in turn cause a dramatical decrease or even disappearance of catalytic activity. In heterogeneous catalysis, the adsorption energies of reactants and intermediates have a significant impact on the catalytic activities, which have been suggested as a descriptor of catalytic performance. For HEA-NPs, the diverse composition leads to the multiformity of the coordination environment for the adsorption sites. Therefore, the surface structure of the catalysts can be modified precisely by regulating the composition [73,75]. For example, Batchelor et al. [76] proposed a predictable model based on the local site environment on the surface. The authors constructed a database of adsorption energy by calculating OH* and O* binding at different unit cells on IrPdPtRhRu HEA surface. Further, owing to the tailorable composition of HEAs, composition optimization was successfully realized by setting the ΔE opt of 1.1 eV which was close to the peak of the Volcano curve (it was highlighted the optimal adsorption energy of OH* was ∼0.1 eV higher than on Pt (111) surface with a ΔE OH* of 1.0 eV for ORR). The results confirmed that Ir10.2Pd32.0Pt9.30Rh19.6Ru28.9 HEAs presented a 5 times higher calculated activity and a reduced overpotential of 0.04 V than pure Pt (111) surface. Even though Pd81.7Ru18.3 and Ir17.5Pt82.5 exhibited better calculated activity, they were unable to form stable binary alloys, suggesting that five elements acted as not only adsorption energy regulators but also structural stabilizers [77,78]. The aforementioned work exploited a methodology to identify the composition corresponding to the adsorption energy of an intermediate which was the key descriptor. However, the structure–property relationship has not been established in electrocatalysis, which should be the focus in the future research. Noble metals are of huge demand towards the field of industrial catalysis, which play extremely important roles in the industrial application and energy conversion [79,80]. The limited resources of noble metals drive to seek alternatives or reduce the usage of noble metals. Alloying the noble metals to form HEAs is an effective strategy to increase the intrinsic catalytic activity and thus reduce the usage of noble metals [81]. Flexible modulation capability of HEAs provides a platform for exploring efficient and stable catalysts. However, the performance of multi-component catalysts does not simply depend on the chemical nature of each element. The order of the crystal lattice and the disorder of the element occupancy should be taken into account, making the properties of each element more complicated than the superposition of the average properties of its components. Moreover, the structure–property relationship varies from the type of catalytic reactions. Therefore, we will discuss some typical electrocatalytic applications of noble-metal-based HEA catalysts and their corresponding structure–property relationships. 2 Noble-metal-based HEAs for electrocatalysis 2.1 Electrolysis of water Hydrogen can be obtained by the electrolysis of water, which is a promising process to minimize the emission of CO2. The electrolysis of water contains two half-reactions of the anodic reaction producing oxygen gas and the cathodic reaction producing hydrogen gas. Thermodynamically, the overall potential for water electrolysis is 1.23 V vs. RHE. However, the presence of overpotentials at both sides makes the applied potential much larger than 1.23 V vs. RHE. Therefore, it is significant to seek highly efficient catalysts which require low overall potentials for water electrolysis. 2.1.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction HER is a half-reaction of water splitting, consisting of multi-step elementary reactions occurring on catalyst surface. Studies have shown that HER activity is highly sensitive to pH and follows different reaction pathways under acidic and alkaline conditions [82]. Pt (Ru, Pd)-based catalysts were deemed to be theoretically highly active for HER [83–87], but suffered from poor corrosion resistance and short-term stability in the acidic electrolytes, as well as high reaction energy barrier in the alkaline electrolytes. Owing to the unique physical and chemical properties, HEA catalysts provided a new angle in improving the catalytic activity and stability. By alloying noble metals, it is likely to obtain highly active and stable electrocatalysts in the alkaline electrolytes. Liu et al. prepared ternary PtAuPd, quaternary PtAuPdRh, and quinary PtAuPdRhRu alloy NPs by an ultrasonic-assisted wet chemical method at room temperature [49]. At a current density of 30 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH electrolyte, the overpotential on PtAuPdRhRu HEA-NPs was 190 mV, which was 70 and 410 mV lower than that on PtAuPdRh and PtAuPd-NPs, respectively (Fig. 4 a). Meanwhile, PtAuPdRhRu HEA-NPs presented a smallest Tafel slope of 62 mV dec−1 (Fig. 4b). The authors attributed the improved performance to the synergic effect between high-entropy nanostructures and active metals. Another platinum-group-metals IrPdPtRhRu HEA-NPs were synthesized by a one-pot polyol method [88]. At a potential of 50 mV vs. RHE in the acidic (alkaline) electrolyte, the geometric current density j geo of IrPdPtRhRu HEA-NPs was 3.4 (4.3), 2.5 (8.4), 4.8 (321.5), 1.5 (18.3), and 1.6 (15.2) times higher than that of Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt catalysts, respectively (Fig. 4c and d). Turn over frequency (TOF) value of the HEA-NPs was higher than that of single metal catalysts over the whole potential range of the test (Fig. 4e and f). Among the catalysts involved in the work, IrPdPtRhRu HEA-NPs impressively exhibited higher TOF of 3.2 and 6.4 H2 per second at 50 mV vs. RHE in the acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively, compared with those of highly active catalysts reported under similar conditions including Ru@C2N (1.66 H2 per second) [89], MoS2/NF (1.66 H2 per second) [90], and Au–Ru NWs (0.31 H2 per second) [91]. IrPdPtRhRu HEA-NPs kept good stability at current densities of 10 mA cm−2 geo for 3000 cycles of cyclic voltammetry (CV). It is believed that the HER intrinsic activity of the catalyst is mainly determined by the adsorption energy of the intermediate H species [92]. The metal–H bond of monometallic and many binary alloy catalysts can be derived from the corresponding d-band center. Fig. 4 (g) and (h) showed that a deeper d-band center corresponded to a higher TOF value of HER. However, the d-band center of IrPdPtRhRu HEA-NPs located between Ir and Pt, which corresponded to a high TOF value under acidic and alkaline conditions compared with monometallic NPs. Therefore, the adsorption energies of H species on the active sites of the HEA surface could not be simply estimated by the d-band center theory. Even though the 3d transition metal catalysts were less active for HER, they were able to modify the local electron environment of noble metals as the filling state of d-orbital electrons to enhance HER current and reduce the utilization of noble metals. For instance, FeCoPdIrPt HEA-NPs [41] showed an overpotential of 42 mV in 1 M KOH electrolyte at the current density of 10 mA cm−2, which was 22 mV lower than that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 4i). Moreover, FeCoPdIrPt HEA-NPs exhibited the smallest Tafel slope of 82 mV dec−1 among PtPdIr, Pt, Ir and CoPd (Fig. 4j). Besides, FeCoPdIrPt HEA-NPs displayed long-term stability within 150 h at the current of 10 mA cm−2. Theoretical calculations revealed that the incorporation of transition metals Fe, Co and noble metal Pd was capable to reduce the anti-bonding state of Pt, thereby optimizing the adsorption and desorption of H species and hence improving the HER activity. The extraordinary stability of the quinary HEA-NPs in HER could be attributed to the entropy stability, which inhibited phase separation. Very recently, ultrasmall NiCoFePtRh HEA-NPs with sub-2 nm size synthesized by a facile chemical co-reduction method and achieved superior HER performance in the acidic electrolyte [93]. NiCoFePtRh HEA-NPs typically exhibited a higher mass activity of 28.3 A mg−1 noble metals and TOF of 30.1 s−1 at −0.05 V vs. RHE as compared with commercial Pt/C although the noble metal loading of the HEA-NPs was 38.9 times lower, benefiting from high atom utilization and synergistic effect among the five atoms and optimized hydrogen-adsorption free energies and low activation barriers (Fig. 5 a and b). The NiCoFePtRh HEA-NPs displayed a Tafel slope of 30.1 mV dec−1, implying the Volmer-Tafel mechanism as the HER pathway. For the Volmer step, in situ X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) analysis revealed the dramatical variation of the absorption edge of Rh shifting to a lower energy compared to the initial state at 0.05 V vs. RHE, indicating Rh collected numerous electrons and H ions were able to be adsorbed at Rh sites preferentially (Fig. 5c). By comparison, the XANES spectra of Pt, Fe, Ni, and Co shifted slightly at 0.05 V vs. RHE. This result provided direct evidence to confirm that Rh sites contributed greatly to the Volmer step in HER. For Tafel step, density functional theory (DFT) calculations disclosed the activation barriers in terms of fcc-fcc (desorption of two H* at fcc sites), top-fcc (desorption of one H* at top site and another H* at fcc site), and top-top (desorption of two H* at top sites) reaction models in HEA (111) and Pt/C (111) surface. The activation barriers of fccRh-fccPt model (H* at the fccRh site migrates onto the fccPt site before desorption at θ H ∗ = 15 16 ), topPt/Rh/Fe/Co/Ni-fccPt model and topPt/Fe/Co/Ni-topPt model were only 0.651, 0.238 and 0.231 eV, significantly lower than corresponding Pt (111) surface (Fig. 5e–p). In addition, the white line of the Pt XANES edge declined sharply when HER commenced (−0.01 V vs. RHE), suggesting that Pt sites were the main active sites for HER when HEA surface presented a high H* coverage (Fig. 5d). Hence, Rh element contributed enormously to the Volmer step, Pt/Rh element played essential roles in the Tafel step, and the Fe/Co/Ni atoms acted as electronic structure modifiers presenting synergistic effect and high entropy effect. PdFeCoNiCu HEA-NPs (∼34 nm) with a body-centered cubic (bcc) structure exhibited a lower onset potential for HER in the alkaline electrolytes [36]. PdFeCoNiCu HEA nanoparticles showed an overpotential of 18 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, which was 91 mV and 400 mV lower than that of commercial Pt/C and Pd/C, respectively. In addition, the Tafel slope of 39 mV dec−1 of PdFeCoNiCu HEA catalyst was much lower than that of Pt/C (98 mV dec−1) and Pd/C (182 mV dec−1). The authors highlighted that the surface distortion of HEAs caused a step-like surface structure, especially near the Cu sites, resulting in the optimized surface electronic structure. According to the analysis of the site-dependent projected density of states of each metal, Pd enhanced the electroactive adsorption of free-migrating protons in HER process. Fe facilitated the d-d electron binding and could supplement the electron consumption at Co sites. Ni and Co effectively promoted H2O splitting. Cu boosted the overall electron transfer between metal sites. Finally, they found that the energy of each elementary reaction toward hydrogen evolution decreased continuously in the alkaline environment (Fig. 5q), and the activation energy of the rate-limiting step of water splitting was only 0.21 eV (Fig. 5r), which was conducive to the HER activity. In general, the synergistic effect of different metal elements modulated the surface electronic environment of HEAs, enhancing electron transfer and optimizing the binding energy of H species. 2.1.2 Oxygen evolution reaction OER is a key reaction for the electrolysis of water. However, OER is a complex process involving the transfer of 4-electrons coupling with 4-protons, leading to a relatively large overpotential and sluggish reaction kinetics, seriously restricting the efficiency of an energy conversion system [94]. Therefore, developing highly efficient OER catalysts is urgent for water electrolysis to produce highly pure hydrogen. At present, noble metal oxides such as IrO2 and RuO2 and 3d transition metal oxides/hydroxides containing Co, Mn, Ni and Fe are highly active for OER [95–100]. However, these electrocatalysts still face the issues of high-cost and poor stability. Alloying a variety of transition metals to Ir-based and Ru-based catalysts is an efficient and effective strategy [101,102]. Similar to the idea of incorporating the individual properties of dissimilar metals to obtain HEA catalyst for the HER, Pt-based CoFeLaNiPt HEA-NPs with an average radius of ∼320 nm was synthesized by nanodroplet-mediated co-deposition and applied to OER [13]. The HEA-NPs displayed an overpotential of 377 ± 4 mV at the current density of 10 A cm−2, which was comparable to that of the IrO x catalyst (Fig. 6 a). The authors proposed that 3d transition metals were the catalytically active sites for OER process, and the combination of 3d transition metals and noble metals with ideal catalytic performance provided multifunctional catalytic activities for the alloy system. Jin et al. [103] prepared ternary, quaternary, and quinary Ir-based nanoporous HEAs (np-HEAs) by a simple alloying-dealloying method uniformly mixing Ir and other 2 to 4 different metal elements into single-phase nanostructure. Scanning transmission electron microscopy images showed the multi-level ultrafine porous structure of np-AlNiCoIrMo after dealloying. The electrochemical active specific surface area (ECSA) of np-AlNiCoIrMo was 57.6 m2 g−1 Ir, which was higher than that of ternary AlNiIr HEAs (42.5 m2 g−1 Ir), indicating that the quinary np-HEAs structure improved the atomic utilization efficiency of Ir. np-AlNiCoIrMo presented a low onset potential of ∼1.42 V vs. RHE in 0.5 M H2SO4, which was significantly lower than that of IrO2 (∼1.48 V vs. RHE) (Fig. 6b), and exhibited a small Tafel slope of 55.2 mV dec−1 (Fig. 6c). Meanwhile, quinary np-AlNiCoIrMo reached the highest Ir/Ru mass-based activities compared with other reported values of j mass at 1.5 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6d). At a high current density of 60 mA cm−2, quinary np-AlNiCoIrMo, AlNiCoIrCu and AlNiCoIrNb exhibited potential positive-shifts of ∼11.5, ∼2.1, and ∼11 mV after 7000 cycles of CVs, while the ternary np-AlNiIr catalyst showed the largest potential positive-shift of ∼70.3 mV (Fig. 6e). The durability of quinary np-HEAs was significantly improved compared to ternary alloys, which was attributed to the high-entropy stability, lattice distortion effect or sluggish diffusion effect. The authors suggested that the high catalytic activity of np-HEA catalysts compared with commercial IrO2 resulted from the increased covalent bond length of Ir–O. By the theoretical calculations, the absolute value of the difference between the centers of Ir d-band and O p-band was compared. The smaller value represented the stronger covalency of metal–O. The results showed that the covalency of Ir–O was markedly enhanced via alloying of Ni and Mo, resulting in an increased OER current. The calculation of the energy path of the OER process further confirmed that the multi-component system possessed a lower energy barrier than pure IrO2. Therefore, the low Ir loading np-HEA catalyst was able to further improve OER activity. Sequentially, Jin et al. [47] synthesized Ru-based AlNiCoRuX (X: Mo, Co, V, Fe) HEA nanowires with an oxidized surface by alloy-dealloying method, with a diameter ranging from 20 to 100 nm. The Tafel slope of the quinary AlNiCoRuMo catalyst was only 54.5 mV dec−1 in alkaline solution, which was lower than that of commercial RuO2 (Fig. 6f). With the decrease in Ru content, the AlNiCoRuMo catalyst reached a mass current density of ∼300 mA mg−1 Ru at 1.5 V vs. RHE (Fig. 6g). Notably, AlNiCoRuMo showed an excellent stability over 100 h of electrolysis at a high potential of 1.48 V vs. RHE. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) confirmed that AlNiCoRuMo catalyst presented the lowest internal resistance, indicating that the highest electron transfer efficiency between surface and electrode. The surface oxide layer model of the HEAs could be simplified to crystalline NiCo2O4 with inverse spinel structure. The eg occupancy of active cations in the octahedron could be regarded as a descriptor for OER/ORR activity [104]. The binding strength of intermediates in OER process depended on eg-filling and nearly uniform eg-orbitals occupancy. According to theoretical calculations, the calculated |eg − 1| values of Co after doping with the other four kinds of atoms followed the order of Cu > V > Fe > Mo. For Ru, the values followed the order of V = Fe > Cu > Mo. The above results indicated that eg occupancy after Co and Ru doped with Mo was close to unity. Therefore, electron transfer between the surface cations and the adsorbed reaction intermediates would be promoted greatly when the eg orbital filling was close to unity, thus improving the OER activity. In a very recent research, Zhu et al. [105] synthesized ultra-small FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs (∼6 nm) for a highly efficient OER in the acid medium, combining the electrospinning and graphitization process. The electrochemical tests showed that the obtained FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs exhibited an overpotential of 241 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slope of 153 mV dec−1, superior to most reported results in the literatures (Fig. 7 a and b). Moreover, the FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs showed an outstanding mass activity of 205 mA mg−1 Ir+Ru at an overpotential of 270 mV compared with the reported catalysts, and subsequent tests verified the more exposed active sites possessed on HEAs according to the largest C dl (double layer capacitance) value of 205.5 mF cm−2 (Fig. 7c). It is worth mentioning that FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs presented a high stability for up to 14 h at 10 mA cm−2 with a slight degradation, while other Ir-based catalysts exhibited severe decrease (Fig. 7d). In order to provide the more sensitive insights into the intermediates formation and identify the roles of each element in FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs during OER process, in situ Raman spectroelectrochemistry and DFT calculations were performed respectively. As shown in Fig. 7(e), Co-O and Ni-O vibrational peaks became strong and sharp when the potentials varied from open circuit potential (OCP) to 1.45 V vs. RHE, demonstrating the continuously water dissociation into OH*. As the potentials continuously increased from 1.45 V vs. RHE to 2.25 V vs. RHE, the peak intensity of superoxo (OO) species increased, indicating that OO species were formed on FeCoNiIrRu/CNFs HEA-NPs surface through the oxidation of the OH* intermediates (Fig. 7f). The strong OH* and O* adsorption coupled with continuous formation of OOH* species greatly speeded up the reaction kinetics for OER. Subsequently, the theoretical calculation of free energy diagrams for OER on five metal sites of FeCoNiIrRu surfaces was presented (Fig. 7g and h). The greatest free energy variation on Ir sites was as low as 1.67 eV under 0 V vs. RHE, and the oxidation process of OOH* to O2 was highly exothermic on Ir sites. In addition, the electron density redistribution occurred from low electronegative elements (Fe, Co, and Ni) to highly electronegative ones (Ir, Ru) was also proved, implying noble metal sites significantly weakened the adsorption of OH* species so that OOH* species could be favorably adsorbed at Ir and Ru sites to realize sustaining O2 generation (Fig. 7i). 2.2 HEAs for fuel cells 2.2.1 Oxygen reduction reaction ORR as the important half reaction for low temperature fuel cells and metal-air batteries and polymer air batteries is facing the issues of slow kinetics and high overpotentials. Pt-based and Pd-based catalysts are favorable for ORR [106–108], but their low abundance and high-cost limit their large-scale commercial application. In recent years, alloying 3d transition metals such as Fe, Co and Ni promoting ORR activity has become a feasible strategy [109–114]. With the increase of alloying elements, the physicochemical properties of alloy nanoparticles with high mixing entropy were greatly changed. HEA-NPs possessing high entropy-driven stability, modulated atomic constituent, and unique electronic structure are likely to be promising catalysts for ORR. Alloying immiscible elements into a single-phase nanoporous structure is capable to create a huge specific active area for catalytic reactions. Senary AlNiCuPtPdAu and octonary AlNiCuPtPdAuCoFe np-HEAs with fcc structure and the dominant (111) planes were prepared by combining bulk melting, fast cooling and dealloying [43]. Senary np-AlNiCuPtPdAu showed a ligament structure of ∼2–3 nm, possessing high specific surface area. The pore size (∼5–8 nm) was larger than the particle size, enhancing mass transfer of oxygen. Senary np-HEAs exhibited a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of ∼0.90 V vs. RHE for ORR in 0.1 M HClO4 solution, which was more positive than that of commercial Pt/C ∼0.82 V vs. RHE. The specific activity of np-HEAs at 0.9 V vs. RHE was ∼3.2 mA cm−2, 11.4 times higher than that of Pt/C. Even when considering the total mass of Pt, Pd and Au, its mass activity was much higher than ∼0.44 A mg−1 at 0.9 V vs. RHE, the 2020 target value of the U.S. Department of Energy. Besides, the polarization curve of the np-HEA changed only slightly after 100,000 cycles of CV test, while the mass activity of Pt/C decreased by about 35% after 20000 cycles, indicating the outstanding stability and satisfactory durability. The authors suggested that the uniformly mixed PtPdAu surface of np-AlNiCuPtPdAu formed a favorable configuration for ORR, generating a relatively low free energy change for forming the final product of water. In addition, the electronic effects, strain effects, synergistic effects and unique atomic structure were also attributed to high ORR activity. The same synthesis procedure for ternary, quaternary and quinary nanoporous Al-Cu-Ni-Pt-X (X: Mn, Co, Mo, Pd, Au, etc.) HEA catalysts was applied [115]. np-AlCuNiPtMn presented the highest half-wave potential of ∼0.945 V vs. RHE and ∼0.954 V vs. RHE in the acid and alkaline media, respectively (Fig. 8 a–d), where it showed a current density of 5.5 mA cm−2, 16 times higher than commercial Pt/C (Fig. 8e). In comparison with the state-of-the-art ORR catalyst, the HEA catalyst still exhibited a high half-wave potential and a large specific current density (Fig. 8f). Furthermore, the np-AlCuNiPtMn sample showed almost unchanged half-wave potential after 30000 cycles of CV test, and a constant potential of 0.7 V vs. RHE for 164 h, implying the excellent stability and durability. According to first-principles simulations, the authors highlighted that the free energy of O2 → OOH* as the rate-limiting step of ORR was apparently decreased under the equilibrium electrode potential. In addition, the presence of Cu and Ni in the subsurface layer weakened the binding of OOH* adsorbents at the surface layer. Moreover, the addition of Mn did not only reduce the d-band center of Pt, but also further modulated the electronic properties of the catalyst surface and reduced the energy barrier. In conclusion, the Pt surface of np-HEA was modulated by surface stress or ligand effects after the combination of distinct fifth elements, resulting in optimal ORR activity. Chen et al. [116] prepared PdCu@PtNiCo NPs with a core of an intermetallic PdCu and a shell of PtNiCo alloy in fcc phase via seed-mediated co-reduction strategy, which were transformed into PdCuPtNiCo HEA-NPs in a single fcc phase by annealing. PdCuPtNiCo HEAs exhibited the most positive onset potential and half-wave potential compared with Pt NPs and PdCu@PtNiCo core–shell NPs. And the mass current density of the HEA-NPs reached 176.1 mA mg−1 Pt which was 1.95 times and 9.84 times higher than that of PdCu@PtNiCo core–shell NPs and Pt NPs, respectively. Surprisingly, the E 1/2 of PdCuPtNiCo HEAs was even shifted by 5 mV after 10,000 cycles of CV test, implying its high stability. It is noted that Pt shell was formed outside the HEA-NPs after long-time durability test, indicating that Pd, Cu, Ni, and Co atoms were migrated from the surface to the inner of NPs. However, the structure change did not mitigate the catalytic performance, suggesting that Pt-rich surface and the formation of HEA nuclei possessed excellent electronic effects [117]. It can be stated that the highly dispersed Pt/Pd atoms and unique electronic effects were the origin of the high ORR activity of the HEA-NPs. Li et al. [118] obtained single-phase quinary FeCoNiCuPd HEA-NPs with a uniform particle size through a synergistic confinement strategy that effectively restricted the growth of NPs. FeCoNiCuPd HEA-NPs presented the highest half-wave potential E 1/2 of ∼0.85 V vs. RHE and the smallest Tafel slope of 69 mV dec−1 among the catalysts of FeCoNiCu, FeCoNi and commercial Pt. According to Koutecký-Levich equation, the average electron transfer number of the ORR was about 3.8 in the potential window from 0.5 to 0.8 V vs. RHE, indicating that 4-electron transfer process was dominant. The authors attributed the enhanced ORR activity of HEA-NPs to the homogeneous particle distribution and their single solid solution phase structure. The synergistic effect of the five elements in HEA-NPs might be due to the high-entropy effect, enabling them to form a single solid solution phase instead of an intermetallic phase. In addition, the synergistic effect of surface metals with multiple valence states and Pd metals provided a proper binding strength for the reaction intermediates, thus reducing the overpotential of ORR. 2.2.2 Electrochemical oxidation of fuels (1) Methanol oxidation reaction Direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) is a promising power generation device which can directly exploit methanol as anodic reactant to convert the stored chemical energy into electric energy. Benefiting from its low price, convenient transportation and high volumetric specific energy, DMFC can be considered as a kind of mobile and portable device. Although theoretical conversion efficiency of DMFC is as high as 96.5%, the actual efficiency is dramatically reduced owing to the limitation of anode polarization and the high overpotential of methanol oxidation [119–121]. Therefore, it is in great demand to explore efficient catalysts to improve the reaction rate and onset potential of methanol oxidation. Pt-based catalysts are considered to be the noble-metal-based electrocatalysts with the best methanol oxidation activity in the acidic media. However, the intense adsorption of the intermediate CO on the surface will cause poisoning of the catalyst, leading to a severe decrease in the catalytic activity and stability. Accordingly, alloying a second element to modify the electronic structure on catalyst surface is a feasible strategy to improve CO anti-poisoning. Our recent reinvestigation of MOR on Pt-based catalyst showed that the anti-oxidizing during the high potential was very important as well [122]. Binary Pt-based alloys such as PtRu, PtPd, PtAu, PtNi and PtCo have been widely reported [123–127]. In addition, ternary, or even quaternary alloys such as PtRhCu, PtPdCu, PtRuFe, PtCoNiRh, PtRuFeCo have been further investigated as high-efficiency catalysts for methanol electro-oxidation [128–132]. The synergistic effect of multiple elements results in the optimization of the structure, composition, and surface, enriching the coordination environment around Pt active atoms and then enhancing CO tolerance. As early as 2008, Tsai et al. [133] applied single-phase Pt50Fe11Co10Ni11Cu10Ag8 HEA-NPs prepared by sputtering deposition method to the MOR. The molar ratio of the constituent elements Pt:Fe:Co:Ni:Cu:Ag was roughly equal to 5:1:1:1:1:1. According to Boltzmann hypothesis theory, the configuration entropy of synthesized senary alloys could be expressed as: (4) Δ S c o n f = - R 1 2 l n 1 2 + 5 × 1 10 l n 1 10 = 1.498 R J K - 1 m o l - 1 , The value was slightly lower than the configuration entropy of 1.729R of its corresponding high-entropy-alloy system with an equal atomic ratio. The catalytic activity of methanol electro-oxidation on the HEA-NPs was higher than that of Pt, but lower than that of Pt43Ru57. The authors proposed that a moderate increase in entropy might be beneficial to the enhancement of activity. Inspired by the improvement of mechanical properties and oxidation stability of hexagonal close-packed (hcp) metals (Os, Re, Ru, and Zr), namely the ‘rhenium effect’, Yusenko et al. [46] obtained HEA-NPs with fcc, hcp and fcc + hcp structures by modulating phase ratio of hcp/fcc. Among them, Ir0.19Os0.22Re0.21Rh0.20Ru0.19 NPs with hcp structure exhibited high performance of the electro-oxidation of methanol. The authors believed that the high activity was due to the unique electronic effect and synergistic effect resulting from alloying. The former is that the alloyed metal moderately adjusted the electronic structure of Pt atoms, thereby weakening the adsorption of COads and allowing it to be easily removed, eventually making the methanol molecules in solution accessible to the catalysts surface. The latter means that transition metals in HEA-NPs supplied active surface oxidative species which oxidize those adsorbed intermediates at low potential. Furthermore, the interaction of pristine elements in terms of CuAgAuPtPd HEA-NPs with equal atomic ratio was investigated (Fig. 9 a–d) [134]. In MOR, the peak current of CuAgAuPtPd HEA-NPs was higher than that of Pt nanoparticles. Additionally, the ratio of the forward peak current (i f) to reverse peak current (i r) of HEA-NPs was about 4 times higher than that of conventional Pt nanoparticles (i f/i r = 1) (Fig. 9e). By monitoring the amount of CO production, less CO production was observed on the quinary alloy catalyst, indicating superior CO tolerance (Fig. 9f). Compared the surface (111) of alloyed elements with pristine metals, the d-band center of metals except Au was closer to the Fermi level after alloying, leading to the enhancement of activity (Fig. 9g). The authors suggested that Pt acted as catalytic active site and behaved like a ‘single atom catalyst’ due to the homogeneous dispersion of Pt without Pt-Pt coordination in HEA-NPs. Furthermore, the synergistic effect of multi-component further played a positive role in the activity towards methanol electro-oxidation as well. Uniform and small Pt18Ni26Fe15Co14Cu27 HEA-NPs obtained by Li et al. [135] exhibited excellent electrocatalytic properties for HER and MOR. The HEA-NPs catalysts showed a higher specific peak current of 114.93 mA cm−2 for methanol electro-oxidation and a lower onset oxidation potential than commercial Pt/C in the alkaline electrolyte. After 1000 CV cycles, the mass activity was only decreased by 6.4% (Fig. 10 a–c). Assisted by DFT calculations, they claimed that the most stable adsorption sites for CH3OH and H2O located adjacent to Ni and Fe sites, while OH was stably adsorbed on hollow sites, and H tended to be adsorbed on the sites adjacent to Ni and Co. As a consequence, multiple adsorption sites resulted in opportune adsorption of key intermediates and fast electron transfer during MOR, which predominantly improved the utilization of surface electro-activity. Two reaction pathways toward CO2 and CO were proposed. The energy path diagram for CO2 production showed that the rate-limiting step was TS4 with an activation energy of 0.64 eV (Fig. 10d). While the energy path of CO generation shows that TS2 was the rate-limiting step with an activation energy of 0.94 eV (Fig. 10e). Therefore, the generation of CO was not facilitated on the HEA surface. In sum, HEAs provided a suitable electronic environment and multiple active sites to maximize the electrocatalytic activity. To verify that compressive strain as a key factor to enhance the catalytic activity of HEAs, a surface strain strategy [136] was utilized to control the thermal reduction temperature for synthesizing PtFeCoNiCu HEAs, denoted as HEA-700 (treated at 700 °C) and HEA-400 (treated at 400 °C), respectively. HEA-700 presented a compressive strain of 0.94% compared to HEA-400. In the acidic electrolyte, the specific currents of HEA-400 and HEA-700 were 2.35 and 3.29 mA cm−2, respectively, which were higher than that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 11 a). In addition, HEA-700 had better capability in CO anti-poisoning indicated by the CO electrochemically oxidative stripping result (Fig. 11b). The DFT calculations evidenced that the Pt–Pt bond distance in HEA-700 was shorter than that of the Pt (111) plane because the transition metals possessed smaller atomic radii than that of Pt, resulting in a compression strain on the surface Pt layer (Fig. 11c). Hence, the resulted HEA-700 surface with shorter Pt–Pt bond distance was able to weaken CO adsorption (Fig. 11d) [137]. Besides, the compressive strain of HEAs caused the d-band center of the surface Pt layer to move away from the Fermi level, indicating that multiple components were capable to further modulate the electronic structure of HEA surface. Therefore, the electrons transfer from transition metals in HEA-700 core to the surface Pt layer generated compressive strain and downshifted d-band centers, thereby improving its CO tolerance and promoting methanol oxidation (Fig. 11e). (2) Ethanol oxidation reaction Direct ethanol fuel cell (DEFC) is another promising electrocatalytic device that receives much more interests and of great potential in recent years [138,139]. Compared with methanol, ethanol is less toxic, and the complete oxidation of ethanol is a 12-proton/electron transfer process, thus obtaining high theoretical energy density [140]. Ethanol containing C–C, C–H, C–O, and O–H bonds is a typical model organic molecule, which can be applied in fundamental researches [141]. Pt and Pd catalysts are recognized as highly active EOR catalysts in the acidic and alkaline electrolytes, respectively. Recently, although Pt-based and Pd-based multi-elemental alloys exhibited higher EOR electrocatalytic activity and CO tolerance than pristine metals, completely breaking the C–C bond is still a big challenge [142–146]. EOR involves many steps such as dehydrogenation, C–C bond splitting, oxidative stripping of the resulted C1 fragments, which required several active sites with different functions. Our recent review of the advance of EOR on Pt-based ternary catalysts suggested that alloying is a feasible strategy to solve the current issues of EOR [145]. Therefore, forming noble-metal-based HEAs is potential to accelerate the kinetics of the EOR to achieve 12 proton/electron transfer. In 2020, small and homogeneously dispersed senary platinum-group metals (PGM) HEA-NPs with fcc structure were prepared via a facile polyols liquid phase reduction method and applied to EOR [42]. Surprisingly, the RuRhPdOsIrPt HEA-NPs displayed an extraordinary activity for EOR. The specific current of PGM HEA-NPs at 0.45 V vs. RHE was 2.5 times, 6.1 and 12.8 times higher than those of commercial Pd/C, Pd black and Pt/C catalysts, respectively (Fig. 12 a and b). Particularly, PGM HEA-NPs presented a lower onset potential and higher current density at 0.6 V vs. RHE than Au@PtIr/C which exhibited the highest activity of EOR to date (Fig. 12c and d) [147]. The author compared the electrocatalytic EOR performance of each monometallic catalyst and proposed that Pt exhibited the intrinsic activity for EOR, Pd was able to improve CO tolerance, Rh and Ir were conducive to C–C bond breaking, Ru and Os were in favor of the adsorption of OH species. The EOR activities of single metal, ternary alloy, quaternary alloy, quinary alloy and PGM HEA-NPs at the low potential of 0.26–0.4 V vs. RHE followed the order: PGM HEA-NPs ≫ IrPdPtRhRu > IrPdPtRh ≈ PdPtRh ≥ Pd (Fig. 12e and f). The results above further revealed that the coordination environment of surface active metal sites was capable to be continuously modulated by changing the composition. The promoted EOR current was observed on np-AlPdNiCuMo HEAs in the assembled DEFC as well [148]. The quinary np-AlPdNiCuMo possessed a high ECSA of 88.53 m2 g−1 Pd and exhibited good EOR performance of 2.67 A mg−1 Pd in 1 M KOH/0.5 M ethanol (Fig. 12g). In addition, it showed excellent activity retention for 250 min (Fig. 12h). Scanning electron microscope and dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy characterization showed that the materials presented ∼2 nm ultrafine and multi-level nanopores, making a high specific surface area, thus enhancing the EOR current. CV curves for EOR showed that np-AlPdNiCuMo exhibited the highest electrocatalytic activity compared with other synthesized quinary alloys (Fig. 12i). The authors proposed that multi-element alloy composition was able to better adjust the electronic structure of the Pd atoms on the surface. (3) Formic acid oxidation reaction The electro-oxidation of formic acid is one of the most crucial research regarding commercialized direct formic acid fuel cell (DFAFC), for which Pt and Pd are regarded as state-of-the-art monometallic anode catalysts [149,150]. Nevertheless, both Pt and Pd pristine catalysts are arduous to match the harsh condition in practical application. Pt catalysts face the challenge of high energy barrier for direct formic acid oxidation and strong Pt–CO* binding, while Pd catalysts present poor acid resistance [151]. A series of constitute and composition modulation strategies have been studied extensively for pursuing high catalytic reactivity, stability and selectivity. Among them, noble-metal-based binary Pt/Pd nanoparticles, Cu5Pt nanoframes and core–shell Au@Pt nanoparticles are synthesized and exhibit remarkable formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) performance [149,151,152]. In addition to the unique MOR property, we have discussed previously, the CuAgAuPtPd HEA-NPs displayed outstanding FAOR performance as well [134]. The experimental results showed that the onset of oxidation was at zero bias with the current of ∼3.5 mA (Fig. 13 a). A significant amount of CO2 and H2 were observed at 0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), substantiating the spontaneous oxidation of formate ion on CuAgAuPtPd HEA-NPs surface (Fig. 13b). Moreover, the molar ratio of CO2/CO produced in HEAs was as high as 65.9:1 at 0.7 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), revealing the dominance of direct oxidation pathway in formic acid (Fig. 13c). As shown in Fig. 13(d and e), the proposed mechanism elaborated the superior activity of CuAgAuPtPd HEA-NPs. On the one hand, HEA surface derived faster formate decomposition from an intense endothermic process, compared to Pt (111) surface. On the other hand, the adsorption energy of formate intermediate was more positive on the HEA surface, leading to lesser residence time of formate on the HEA surface, agreeing well with experimental observations. (4) Hydrogen oxidation reaction Hydrogen fuel cell is a clean and efficient energy conversion device due to its high energy conversion rate, zero carbon emission and noise-free. The HOR kinetics on the electrode is controlled by the anode catalyst, which is the main factor affecting the H–H bond rupture and electron transfer [153]. Although the low loading of noble metal Pt (0.05 mgPt cm−2) is able to guarantee satisfying HOR performance of hydrogen fuel cell in the acid medium, the main challenge in anode electrocatalyst lies in the sluggish kinetics in the alkaline medium [154,155]. Even for Pt/C electrocatalyst, the HOR kinetics in the alkaline medium is two orders of magnitude lower than that in the acidic proton exchange membrane medium [156]. Pt-based alloys have been developed to fulfill the fine control of electronic structure, thus leading to the enhancement of the catalytic activity for HOR [157–160]. As advanced catalysts with huge potential in electrocatalysis, HEAs provide the entropy-stabilized nature to incorporate four or more elements into Pt, resulting in optimized activity and stability of Pt-based catalysts. Therefore, it is of great significance to explore optimal composition of HEAs to boost HOR performance. For instance, Zhan et al. [161] manufactured PtRuNiCoFeMo HEA subnanometer nanowires (SNWs) as highly effective and durable catalyst for alkaline HOR, via a facile liquid phase co-reduction method. As shown in Fig. 14 (a), the anode current of HEA SNWs/C increased sharply and showed a high and steady current density with the increased potential, suggesting an excellent HOR property. Additionally, the HEA SNWs/C reached a high mass activity of 6.75 A mg−1 Pt+Ru (specific activity of 8.96 mA cm−2), which is 2.8 (2.6), 4.1 (2.4), and 19.8 (18.7) times higher than that of PtRuNiCoFeMo HEA NPs/C, PtRu/C and Pt/C, respectively (Fig. 14b). After 2000 cycles of accelerated durability test, only 6.2% decrease in mass activity was presented for HEA SNWs/C (Fig. 14c). Moreover, the markedly enhanced resistance to CO poisoning of HEA SNWs/C was elucidated in the presence of 1000 ppm CO (Fig. 14d). Mechanistically, HEA SNWs/C presented the lowest d-band center among the compared samples, indicating that HEA SNWs/C was capable to weaken the adsorption of H but facilitate the adsorption of OH intermediate (Fig. 14e). In particular, the positively shifted CO stripping peak further implied the presence of Ru and downshift of d-band significantly. The projected partial density of states confirmed the accelerated site-to-site electron transfer (Fig. 14f). The results showed that Ni-3d, Co-3d, Fe-3d and Mo-4d orbital exhibited the sharp peaks near −1.30 eV, while Pt-5d orbital located at the furthest position to Fermi level. In addition, the Ru-4d orbital ranged from −6.0 to +4.0 eV, suggesting that Ru served as the electron reservoir to balance the valence state of HEA NWs/C during electrocatalysis. Specifically, Ru enabled accelerated the site-to-site electron transfer on the HEA surfaces, Pt sites possessed an appropriate level of Pt-5d band for suitable H2 adsorption, Ni sites increased the possibilities for OH* bonding and promoted intra-orbital eg-t2g electron transfer, Co sites kept a robust electronic structure from the bulk to the surface, Fe and Mo sites exhibited a decrease of eg-t2g band splitting for 3d orbitals occurred to boost electron transfer towards OH*. The entire HOR on HEAs was exothermic with an energy release of 0.22 eV, in contract with the endothermic energies of 0.57 and 0.27 eV on Pt and PtRu, respectively (Fig. 14g). On the whole, the efficient electron transfer originated from the strong synergy between six elements, which greatly regulated the binding strength of H* and OH* for outstanding HOR. 2.3 HEAs for electrochemical synthesis Electrochemically synthesizing small organic chemicals has been developed including the production of methanol, formic acid, acetate, ethane, ethene, and ethanol by the electroreduction of CO [162–166], and CO2 [167–169], and the electrochemical oxidation of methane [170,171]. Electrochemical synthesis of ammonia has been developed as well [172–174]. In addition, the electrochemical synthesis biofuels and chemicals have been paid an increasing attention [175–177]. It is critical to develop highly efficient catalysts for the electrochemical processes. Therefore, HEAs have a big potential in the electrocatalytic synthesis. 2.3.1 CO2 reduction reaction Electrocatalytic CO2RR as a key step in the artificial carbon cycle can convert CO2 into high value-added chemicals, so as to achieve renewable energy utilization and mitigate the greenhouse effect [178]. Cu-based catalysts are regarded as feasible catalysts to convert CO2 into hydrocarbons [179]. However, pristine Cu-based catalysts presented low selectivity due to competitive hydrogen evolution reactions, and excessively high potentials. Recently, bimetallic nanomaterials have been applied to accelerate consecutive electron/proton transfer of CO2RR, but the Faraday efficiency (FE%) of CO and H2 remains high [180]. Optimized catalytic surface can significantly improve the selectivity and FE% of the desired products. HEAs possessed a simple single solid solution phase and modulated stoichiometric number, rendering them as favorable candidates for better catalysis, as well as distinctive platforms to probe the synergetic mechanism among different atoms during CO2RR. Unique synergistic effect of noble-metal-baesd HEA-NPs has been proved to be favorable for CoNiCuRuPd HEA-NPs as a robust catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation [181], and AgAuCuPdPt HEA-NPs theoretically presented as a new catalyst candidates for the CO2RR and CORR by combining DFT with supervised machine learning [182]. Experimentally, Nellaiappan et al. [182] prepared AuAgPtPdCu HEA-NPs (16 ± 10 nm) with fcc structure via melting and cryogrinding. When applying for CO2RR, the current density reached 10.15 mA cm−2 at the potential of −0.8 V vs. Ag/AgCl in the CO2-saturated K2SO4 electrolyte, which was 5 times higher than in the N2-saturated electrolyte (2.2 mA cm−2) (Fig. 15 a). Besides, the products of CO, CH4, C2H4 and H2 were detected on AuAgPtPdCu HEA-NPs in the potential window from −0.7 to −0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The FE% of CO was ∼4%–7%, while the FE% of H2 was ∼26%, which did not change significantly with the potential. CH4 and C2H4 were the major products with the FE% of ∼70% (Fig. 15b and c). Notably, the total FE% of gas products was almost 100% at −0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl (−0.3 V vs. RHE), indicating that there was almost no liquid products. Otherwise, AuAgPtPdCu NPs exhibited a remarkable stability during 5 h electrolysis. DFT calculations showed that the d-band centers (E dBC) of the two spin configurations of Pd11 atom were both closest to Fermi level (E F), which might be related to the catalytic active center (Fig. 15d). The adsorption energies( Δ E i n t e r a d s )of all intermediates in the CO2RR process were calculated, and converted into the adsorption Gibbs free energies by the following formula: (5) G i n t e r a d s = Δ E i n t e r a d s + Δ Z P E - T Δ S - Δ G U , where ΔZPE is the difference in zero-point energies, ΔS is the change in entropy owing to vibrational contributions, and ΔG U = −eU, in which U is the working electrode potential. The results showed that for the Cu (111) surface, the transition from *OCH3 to *O presented the highest energy barrier of 1.91 eV, which was the rate-determining step for CO2RR process (Fig. 15e). However, on the HEA surface, this process only required an energy barrier of 1.35 eV. In the free energy path diagram, the conversion from *OCH3 to *O on the Cu (111) surface was still a climbing process, and more additional potential was required to overcome this energy barrier (Fig. 15f), implying CO2RR process was more likely to occur on the HEA surface rather than Cu (111) facet. The authors suggested that the above results could be attributed to the weak binding of *OCH3 and the strong binding of *O on HEA surface. The stable *O further promoted the reaction rate-determining step, and the theoretical limit potential was drastically decreased. In this work, the origin of the low selectivity of CO and H2 was further studied. The results showed that the free energy of CO adsorption was −1.01 eV, which was a strong exothermic process, making the desorption of CO difficult from the HEA surface (Fig. 15g). The free energy of H adsorption was −0.45 eV, and for high-efficiency hydrogen evolution catalysts this value was usually thermally neutral (Fig. 15h). Therefore, AuAgPtPdCu HEA-NPs exhibited lower selectivity to CO and H2, and were more inclined to generate CH4 and C2H4. 2.3.2 Nitrogen reduction reaction Ammonia is widely exploited in industrial and agricultural production, which is one of the most crucial chemical raw materials for human being. Owing to the huge energy consumption, expensive high purity hydrogen and large amount of greenhouse gas emissions during the conventional Haber-Bosch process, the electrochemical ammonia synthesis approach has attracted much attention recently [183,184]. Unfortunately, N2 at room temperature and pressure shows high stability, which is hard to be chemically adsorbed. What is more, HER competing with N2RR is more thermodynamically favorable, resulting in a severe decrease in the FE% and yield of ammonia [185]. Accordingly, it is of great significance to search for catalysts with high selectivity and stability for N2RR. HEAs as a new class of material with high modulability may provide a variety of active sites, which is expected to be a proper N2RR catalyst. As for ammonia thermal conversion, RuRhCoNi NPs achieved outstanding performance due to the synergistic effect of multi-elemental mixing, their small size, and the alloy phase [186]. When it turns to electro-reduction of N2 to obtain ammonia, RuFeCoNiCu HEA-NPs with uniform particle size of ∼16 nm in the oil phase under atmospheric pressure was prepared and applied to N2RR [186], showing the NH3 yield of 57.1 µg h−1 mg−1 cat and the FE% of 38.5% at 0.05 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KOH solution saturated with N2 (Fig. 16 a). Moreover, the NH3 yield and the corresponding FE% of RuFeCoNiCu HEA-NPs in 0.1 M Li2SO4, 0.1 M Na2SO4, and 0.1 M HCl were 52.6, 47.2, 37.1 µg h−1 mg−1 cat and 27.6%, 21.2%, 7.7%, respectively (Fig. 16b), verifying that the HEA-NPs exhibited excellent N2RR activity and selectivity in the aqueous media. Otherwise, the degradation of catalytic activity or selectivity over RuFeCoNiCu HEA-NPs was not observed for 100 h catalytic test due to the chemical stability of high-entropy. Using theoretical calculations, the free energy changes of N2RR process for all possible N2 adsorption sites (including top, bridge, and hollow sites) such as t-Fe, h-Co-Ni-Ni, b-Fe-Fe and s-Ni-Ru sites were analyzed (Fig. 16c). For t-Fe and h-Co-Ni-Ni sites, the potential-determination step (PDS) of the N2RR process was *NNH + H → *NNH2, while it was *N + H → *NH for b-Fe-Fe sites (Fig. 16d–f). The above steps were accompanied by maximum changes of Gibbs free energy with 0.32, 0.51 and 0.81 eV, which were all lower than the corresponding values for pristine metals. Among them, two NH3 release processes at t-Fe site were exothermic and thermodynamically favorable. As for s-Ni-Ru site, although the second hydrogenation was accompanied by the increase of Gibbs free energy of 1.98 eV, the first hydrogenation process *N2 + H → *NNH was still an exothermic process, while the latter was considered as the PDS of N2RR process according to previous theoretical studies (Fig. 16g) [187–189]. In conclusion, the synergistic effects of multiple active sites jointly promoted the ultimate catalytic activity. As for the mechanism of HER inhibition, the authors claimed that multiple H atoms were adsorbed at the hollow sites. Therefore, dihydrogen tended to be adsorbed on the hollow sites around the t-Fe sites with the best N2RR activity, and the exposed vertices were capable to adsorb N2 effectively due to the rapidly reduced adsorption energy. The H coverage effect predominantly affected the t-Fe sites. Eventually, different metals might play distinct roles via a synergistic mechanism, resulting in excellent N2RR performance. Furthermore, HEAs were able to shorten the distance between active sites and possess a wide space for composition optimization, which provided a new idea for rational design of efficient N2RR catalysts. 3 Structure–property relationship in noble-metal-based HEA-NPs towards electrocatalysis Structure–property relationship is fundamental in understanding and optimizing an electrochemical process. As shown in Table 1 , HEA materials and their applications in electrocatalysis are summarized. It is apparently observed that the HEA catalysts containing noble metals exhibited higher activity over the monometallic and commercial catalysts. Generally, noble metals such as Pt, Ru, Pd and Ir with superior intrinsic activity for some important reactions including water splitting, oxygen reduction and methanol/ethanol oxidation, were considered as the main active sites while alloying metals provided a synergetic effect [42,116,133,191]. Whereas transition metal Cu was regarded as the active metal for CO2 reduction reaction due to its ability to convert CO2 into hydrocarbon compounds [182]. The synergetic effects associated with surface strain, ligands surrounding active metal and catalytic ensemble was able to tune the chemisorption of intermediates and reactants, which played a significant role in enhancing catalyst activity. For achieving this, several key factors were carefully discussed to direct the design of noble-metal-based HEA-NPs. 3.1 Selection of constituent elements It is obviously that the most tunable and significant factor was altering the composition of HEAs, because the component and ratio of metals were capable to be changed by controlling precursor dosage and directly determined the possible adsorption–desorption model of adsorbates via the modulation of lattice constant and substituted atoms. For noble metal alloying, there are two feasible paths to select the constituent elements based on d-band center. Firstly, choosing reasonable alloying elements according to tailorable lattice strain. Noble metals are classified as late transition metals (LTM) with a d-band exceeding half filled, manifesting that their d-band changes following the reverse principle in terms of early transition metals (ETM) [195]. An alloy system containing atoms with different atomic radii will create tensile or compressive strain, inducing the drift of d-band center. That is, the compressive strain acting on a noble metal (LTM) atom will strengthen the interaction between its d orbitals of neighboring atoms, resulting in the broadening of d-band width owing to dispersion of energies distribution, while a downshifting d-band center occur to guarantee the degree of d-band filling, in contrast to what is observed by tensile strain (Fig. 17 ). In other words, strain modulates the average energy of the d-band so that the chemical properties of catalytic surface will be modified significantly. For instance, it has been proved that the influence of compressive strain on the catalytic activity of surface Pt layer towards the methanol electro-oxidation is in a controllable and predictable way [136]. The selected alloying metals of Fe, Co, Cu, Ni with smaller atomic radii than Pt were able to boost the MOR performance attributed to a shorter Pt–Pt bond distance in PtFeCoNiCu HEA-NPs, and a high temperature treatment at 700 °C contributed to severe compressive strain as well. The downshift d-band center of Pt caused a weaker adsorption of CO, thus a high CO tolerance was obtained. Secondly, selecting suitable alloying element according to analyzable ligand effect. As for alloy systems, charge transfer occurs between different atoms randomly distributed, which is a consequence of the distinct work functions for metallic components [196]. It is affected by the atoms around the binding sides, and a slight perturbation of d-band center emerges. Therefore, ligand effect shows an important influence on the enhancement of catalytic activity. For example, alloying Pd with more electronegative Au/Pt could theoretically reduce the electron density, leading to a downshift of d-band center for Pd due to the supplementary d electrons from Au/Pt, which resulted in a decreased selectivity of CO [197–199]. In addition, it has been investigated that the second metals in PdM (M represents a metal atom) affected the ratio of CO/H2 products because of the different activation ability of H* and HOCO* to generate H2 and CO, which followed the order of PdPt < PdCo < Pd < PdNi < PdCu < PdAg [200]. The works mentioned above provided a foreseeable trend, that is, alloying Pd with Pt, Au, Cu and Ag was capable of reducing hydrogen evolution and balancing the CO binding during CO2RR in a more refined way. Expectedly, Nellaiappan et al. synthesized AuAgPtPdCu NPs and used for CO2RR, impressive FE of methane (38.0%) and ethene (29.5%) at −0.9 V vs. Ag/AgCl were observed, implying that the theory of ligand effect was reasonable to guide the design of unknown HEA-NPs [182]. 3.2 Interaction between HEA-NPs and support Supports are not only considered to be applied to load and stabilize NPs through defects and charge transfer, but also act as a promoter or even a catalytic active component to participate into catalysis, motivating the metal reactivity synergistically [30]. It is worth mentioning that HEAs are in general highly active without any substrate, but it is possible to disperse them on a substrate to increase the activity based on the metal-support interaction (MSI). Carbon-based supports such as carbon black, carbon nanotubes, and graphene are widely used for noble metal NPs loading because of their large surface area and porous structure [201–203]. The heteroatoms doped carbon support can form strong covalent bonding with NPs due to the difference of the work function of the support and NPs (Fig. 18 a), making electron transfer and hence modulating the electronic properties of HEA-NPs [24,66,118,204–206]. Very recently, it has been demonstrated that nanostructured high entropy oxides are promising substrate materials considering their high-entropy stabilization effect, regulable element combination/electronic structure, and multifunctionality properties. The np-AlCoFeCrMo HEOs supporting with PtPdCuAgAu HEA-NPs or highly dispersed Pt clusters which were less active for OER obtained enhanced catalytic performance [207]. Using theoretical calculations, the deposition of Pt clusters on the MoCr-doped CoFe2O4 surface provided a larger DOS near the Fermi level for the composite system, implying a strong interaction between NPs and HEO substrate. This model uncovered a novel methodology for designing applicable high-entropy substrates which were possible to possess unique interaction with noble-metal-based HEAs for electrocatalysis. In addition, more substrate materials including metal oxides and metal carbides with great conductivity are promising to realize innovative synergetic mechanism. In addition, the intensive interaction between NPs and support can also induce different geometry. The surface geometry played a significant role in catalysis, which should be studied in supported HEA-NPs system (Fig. 18b). 3.3 Particle size effect and local coordinating environment The size of HEA-NPs plays a decisive role for changing geometric and electronic properties of NPs, vastly different from their bulk counterparts, and element distribution is related with crystalline and electronic structure [208]. These factors dramatically affect the selectivity and activity of catalysts by varying the adsorption configurations of reactant or intermediates [209]. Single-phase HEAs can be obtained once suitable synthetic methods are exploited, so the element distribution is more easily regulated than the particle size. Hence, size-dependent geometric and electronic properties are decisive to be considered. Geometrically, the surface morphologies of HEA-NPs are changed simultaneously with the particle size variation, and the most prominent alteration is the ratio of low-coordinated metal atoms at edges and corners (LCSs) and high-coordinated sites on terraces (HCSs) as shown in Fig. 19 [208,210,211]. Taking Pt NPs as an representative example, as the particle size decreases from 5.1 to 3.0 nm, the percentage of LCS atoms increases from 7% to 20%, while the percentage of HCS atoms increases from 21% to 25% [212]. Electronically, drastic changes in the energy levels occur as the particle size to be downsized into nanoscale, resulting in discrete states of valence band which are in sharp contrast to that in bulk (Fig. 19) [213,214]. The significant electronic structure variation affects the orbital hybridization and overall charge transfer between metal and reactants, thus tailoring the electrocatalytic performance markedly. Thanks to the efforts from a number of groups, the size-dependent properties of monometallic NPs have been widely explored [215–218]. However, it remains a challenge to comprehensively investigate the relationship between the HEA-NPs size and their structure sensitivity catalytic properties owing to their intricate multiple components. Compared with the binary, ternary and quaternary alloy counterparts, the HEA-NPs exhibit much more atomic arrangements and numerous possible configurations as shown in Fig. 20 . The ordering properties of the HEAs will show significant influence on the electrocatalysis through tuning the adsorption of reactants and intermediates. For pure metallic catalyst, the coordinating atoms and numbers could be identified by detecting the surface structure atomically. However, it is a formidable challenge in identifying the atoms around the center atom. To date, high resolution transmission electron microscopy and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) should be a powerful technique to identify the geometry and atomic arrangement, which will play critical role in structure analysis for HEA-NPs. After the confirmation of the atomic arrangement, the DFT model can be established for investigating the reaction pathways. 4 Summary and prospects This article mainly introduces the concept of HEAs and the ‘core effects’, and summarizes the current progress of noble-metal-based HEA-NPs in the field of electrocatalytic conversion, and further discusses their structure–property relationships. However, the relationship between the surface structure and corresponding properties of HEAs is still elusive, making it difficult to accurately regulate the HEA surface structure and local electronic state. The main viewpoints and difficulties towards the structure–property relationship of HEAs can be summarized as follows. Firstly, in spite of numerous studies of chemical information characterization, the refined analysis of HEAs is still at the initial stage. Chemical valence states of atoms on HEA surface offer an overall chemical information including oxidation states and neighboring coordination environments, showing a prominent correlation with catalytic activity, which can be measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [118,148]. To further confirm the atomic coordination environment and electronic structure of HEAs, X-ray absorption spectroscopy has been applied, including XANES and EXAFS. Among them, XANES is employed to analyze the average chemical states of elements in bulk, and XANES provides a detailed investigation of coordination atom species, coordinate bond length and coordination number [10,30]. Moreover, in situ characterization techniques are used for deeper understanding of the dynamic mechanism and active sites during the synthesis and catalysis process [117,219]. It is reasonable to conclude that the general chemical properties of HEAs are able to be recognized according to the characterization methods mentioned above. However, these characterization analyses are limited by its lack of direct detection of the real active sites because they only offer an average chemical state of a huge and intricate HEA system. Besides, HEAs with compositional multiformity create a complex metal–metal bond system, especially the chemical bond types near the surface active sites, thus it becomes more burdensome to calculate each chemical bond information via computer-assisted technology. Accordingly, a comprehensive theory–experiment-theory method (Fig. 21 ) need to be urgently constructed under the assistance of machine learning, which is helpful to fill the database regarding the chemical state corresponding to the active sites. Secondly, assessing the real surface catalytic ensemble around the active central atom remains a great challenge. A surface atom and its neighboring atoms are capable to construct a catalytic ensemble, and the catalytic property of the ensemble is highly correlated with compositional elements, particle size and substrate. For HEAs, the active sites not only locate on the central atoms, but also the hollow sites or the bridge sites around the central atoms [186]. Besides, the possibilities of the element arrangement of HEAs are numerous, indicating that the number of possible catalytic ensembles is essentially infinite. DFT calculation is a powerful tool for the identification of catalytic ensembles. A feasible route for searching the catalytic sites is to screen out some possible sites according to previous studies first and further calculate the adsorption free energy variation towards key intermediates and reactants. Another feasible route is to compare the influence of a certain element by removing it or replacing with other element so that the possible catalytic ensembles can be verified more clearly.
