For example, it has been demonstrated that np-AlCuNiPtMn exhibited excellent ORR performance by Qiu group. Pt with intrinsic ORR catalytic activity was the focal investigation which might serve as the central atom in a catalytic ensemble [115]. The influence of the additional fifth element to a quaternary alloy was studied by theory calculation, and it was proved that the addition of Mn, Cu and Ni in the subsurface layers was strongly associated with Pt overlayer thickness, resulting in enhanced activity. Therefore, these 3d transition metal elements in the subsurface layers are regard as significant component for catalytic ensemble [115]. However, the work referenced above hardly research the atoms locating in the position except the surface layers and subsurface layers. Clausen et al. [220] pointed out that the atoms in the third layer with fcc (111) metallic structure fourth-nearest to OH adsorption site exhibited dramatically impact on those of second-nearest and third-nearest. In HEAs, identifying specific catalytic ensembles is difficult owing to complicated modulation of electronic and geometric structure. The future study of catalytic ensembles requires innovative big data screening system to narrow down the possible catalytic ensembles, and more precise in situ characterization techniques are beneficial to verify the real catalytic ensembles during catalysis. Thirdly, the adsorption configuration in the atomic level of intermediates and reactants on specific atom in HEAs is difficult to be characterized compared with unary metal catalysts. It has been demonstrated that adsorption energy of the intermediates plays an extremely vital role because the reaction activity is determined by the interfacial electronic coupling [221–223]. Therefore, the reaction rate and selectivity are capable to be described as a function of the adsorption strength, which are plotted in a volcano curve to highlight the catalytic behavior [75,76]. For HEAs, the adsorption state of key intermediates not only hinge on the structural and electronic properties of HEA surface, but also the adsorbate species. Nevertheless, electrocatalytic reaction presents a dynamic process accompanied by complex surface redox variation, especially in a multi-component alloy system, thus remaining a huge challenge to obtain the real adsorption state of a certain atom in HEA-NPs [117]. So far, theoretical calculation has been exploited to simulate the possible adsorption states of key intermediates, but it usually serves as a simplified models [223]. In situ physicochemical analysis is a forceful characterization method and has been successfully utilized for revealing the overall H2 reduction behavior of FeCoNiCuPt HEA-NPs by Song et al. [219] However, accurate adsorption state of a certain atom is difficulted to be studied. Even though Song et al. investigated in detail the chemical composition variation and the behavior of oxidized FeCoNiCuPt HEA-NPs in H2, it still remained a grand challenge to reveal how H2 coupled with a specific atom and verify the fine adsorption configuration of H2 on HEA-NPs surface. To further understand precise adsorption model of key intermediates, it requires advanced in situ characterization techniques and theoretical simulation including in situ TEM, in situ XPS, in situ energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), in situ Raman spectroscopy, DFT calculation, Monte-Carlo molecular dynamics simulation, machine learning, and neural networks. In addition to HEAs, more novel HEMs such as HEMGs [191], HEOs [224–226], high-entropy nitrides (HENs) [227], high-entropy borides (HEBs) [228], high-entropy sulfides (HESs) [229] and high-entropy carbides (HECs) [230] have been successfully synthesized. These high-entropy materials exhibit a long-range crystalline order coexisted with the component disorder, and the same high configurational entropy as HEAs, which are extremely promising towards the field of catalysis. For example, noble-metal-based denary (Hf, Zr, La, V, Ce, Ti, Nd, Gd, Y, Pd)O2− x HEO nanoparticles presented a mass current density of 0.49 A mg−1 Pd for ORR, which was higher than commercial Pd/C and PdO/C, and exhibited an excellent stability after 100 h catalytic test [231]. A highly uniform spherical CoFeNiMnMoPi high-entropy phosphate catalyst exhibited an impressively lower overpotential for OER than many HEO and IrO x catalysts [232]. A quinary (MoWVNbTa)S2 2D high-entropy transition metal dichalcogenide alloys showed the extraordinary selectivity to CO with the FE% of ∼95% for CO2RR [233]. Similarly, it is of great possibility for HEAs to extend the application range towards frontier fields including photocatalysis, photo-thermal catalysis, photo-electrocatalysis and energy storage. The unlimited composition and modulation space of HEAs are conducive to further optimization of their size, morphology, conductivity and catalytic activity. These advantages provide a basis for HEAs to apply in supercapacitors, hydrogen storage materials, lithium-based batteries and solar cells. For the application of supercapacitors, the MnO2-decorated FeCrCoMnNiAl0.75 HEA metallic framework was able to reach a superior specific capacitance of 961 F g−1 at a current density of 5 A g−1, which exhibited huge potential to become alternative materials for high-performance supercapacitors [234]. For the application of Li-based batteries, a series of studies had developed prolongable (Co, Cu, Mg, Ni, Zn)O HEOs family as promising anode/cathode materials [235–237]. Moreover, LiF and Li2O were chosen as the dopants to incorporate into HEOs for promoting ionic and/or electronic conductivity [235]. Even though there is little discussion about the solar cells utilizing HEMs as catalysts at present, reported TiZrHfNbTaO6N3 high-entropy oxynitrides and (Ni40Fe30Co20Al10)90Ti10 HEAs possessed valuable capability for solar energy harvesting, implying the feasibility of fabricating innovative low-bandgap and stable photocatalysis from HEA library [238,239]. Further, new research methods such as machine learning, DFT calculations, and high-throughput technology provide a broad platform for the development of unknown HEA electrocatalysts and the understanding of its structure–property relationship. In summary, the new progress concerning noble-metal-based HEA-NPs is comprehensively summarized in this review in terms of some important electrocatalytic reactions of HER, OER, ORR, MOR, EOR, FAOR, HOR, CO2RR and N2RR, as well as their structure–property relationship. Furthermore, the crucial challenges raised towards HEA surface structure related to property and the new opportunities for this research are carefully discussed. There are numerous open questions and promising directions to be explored, including novel descriptors, design principles, identification of active centers and structure controlling. With the help of advanced syntheses, characterization techniques and data analysis tools, we believe that the challenges above will turn into huge opportunities. Xianfeng Huang received his B.S. degree (2020) in Enzyme Catalysis from Fuzhou University, and he is currently a M.S. student in the School of Biology and Biological Engineering, and the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at South China University of Technology. His research has been focused on the application of electrochemical reactions to energy and environment, especially in noble-metal-based high-entropy-alloys nanoparticles for electrocatalysis. Guangxing Yang received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Chemical Engineering from South China University of Technology in 2008 and 2011, respectively. He received the Ph.D. degree in Chemical Engineering from University of New Hampshire–Durham in 2018. He is currently working at South China University of Technology as a postdoctoral researcher. He focuses on the electrooxidation of alcohols, oxygen reduction reaction, and CO2 conversion to valuable chemicals through electrochemistry and thermal chemistry. Prof. Shuang Li obtained her B.S and Ph.D degrees in Chemical Engineering from Tsinghua University in 2001 and 2006. She currently holds a position as full professor in the School of Biology and Biological Engineering, South China University of Technology. She is interested in aspects of synthetic biology, including theoretical, technical and in its application. She has published more than 40 full papers in peer-reviewed journals and 10 issued patents. Hongjuan Wang is an associate professor in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at South China University of Technology. She received her B.S. degree in Fine Chemical Engineering from Light Industry University of Zheng Zhou in 1997, her M.S. degree in Chemical Engineering from Qingdao University of Science and Technology in 2000, and her Ph.D. degree in Chemical Engineering from South China University of Technology in 2003. Her research is focused on nanomaterials and catalysis for energy and environment. She has contributed more than 50 peer-reviewed papers and 10 patents. Yonghai Cao received his B.E. degree from Xiangtan University in 2009 and Ph.D. degree from South China University of Technology in 2014. He worked as a postdoctoral researcher at South China University of Technology in China and University of Tennessee in United States during 2014–2017. He joined the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at South China University of Technology in 2017. His main research interests focused on the synthesis and application of nanocarbon materials in the field of catalysis and environmental remediation. Prof. Feng Peng received his B.S. degree (1990) and M.S. degree (1993) in Chemical Engineering from Hunan University and his Ph.D. degree in Industrial Catalysis from South China University of Technology in 1996. His research field is nanomaterials and catalysis for energy and environment. He worked at South China University of Technology during 1996–2017. He is currently working in the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Guangzhou University. He has contributed more than 300 peer-reviewed papers and 30 patents. Prof. Hao Yu received his B.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Chemical Engineering from Tsinghua University in 1999 and 2005. He joined South China University of Technology in 2005 and was promoted to full professor of Chemical Engineering in 2013. His research interests are in heterogeneous catalysis, carbon nanomaterials and catalytic reaction engineering. He has contributed more than 200 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Since the two seminal papers were published independently in 2004, high-entropy-alloys (HEAs) have been applied to structural and functional materials due to the enhanced mechanical properties, thermal stability, and electrical conductivity. In recent years, HEA nanoparticles (HEA-NPs) were paid much attention to in the field of catalysis for the promoted catalytic activity. Furthermore, the various ratios among the metal components and tunable bulk and surface structures enable HEAs have big room to enhance the catalytic performance. Especially, noble-metal-based HEAs displayed significantly improved performance in electrocatalysis, where the ‘core effects’ were employed to explain the superior catalytic activity. However, it is insufficient to understand the essential mechanism or further guide the design of electrocatalysts. Structure–property relationship should be disclosed for the catalysis on HEA-NPs to accelerate the process of seeking high effective and efficient electrocatalysts. Therefore, we summarized the recent advances of noble-metal-based HEA-NPs applied to electrocatalysis, such as hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, oxygen reduction reaction, methanol oxidation reaction, ethanol oxidation reaction, formic acid oxidation reaction, hydrogen oxidation reaction, carbon dioxide reduction reaction and nitrogen reduction reaction. For each electrocatalytic reaction, the reaction mechanism and catalyst structure were presented, and then the structure–property relationship was elaborated. The review begins with the development, concept, four ‘core effect’ and synthesis methods of HEAs. Next, the electrocatalytic reactions on noble-metal-based HEA-NPs are summarized and discussed independently. Lastly, the main views and difficulties pertaining to structure–property relationship for HEAs are discussed.
